description: From Middle English cressaunt, from Anglo-Norman cressaunt and Old French creissant (“crescent of the moon”) (French croissant), from Latin crēscēns, present active participle of crēscō (“arise, thrive”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱreh₁- (“to grow”). See Old Armenian սերիմ (serim, “be born”) and սերեմ (serem, “bring forth”), Ancient Greek κόρη (kórē, “girl”) and κούρος (koúros, “boy”), Latin creāre (“produce, create, bring forth”) and Ceres (“goddess of agriculture”). Doublet of croissant.
The pronunciation with /z/ is a comparatively recent innovation due to the influence of words such as pheasant and present.

entries.meaning: (dated, rare) marked by an increase; waxing, like the Moon.
The figure of the moon as it appears between its first or last quarter and the new moon, with concave and convex edges terminating in points.

definitionGroups.group: Something shaped like a crescent, especially:

entries.meaning: A curved street, often presenting a continuous façade, as of row houses.
(Islam) A representation of crescent used as a symbol of Islam.
examples: Turkish flag features a white star and crescent on red base.

entries.meaning: (historical) Any of three orders of knighthood conferred upon foreigners to whom Turkey might be indebted for valuable services.
(heraldry) The emblem of the waxing Moon with horns directed upward, when used in a coat of arms; often used as a mark of cadency to distinguish a second son and his descendants.

verbs.description: crescent (third-person singular simple present crescents, present participle crescenting, simple past and past participle crescented)
